an7.31:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven downfalls for a lay follower …

an7.31:1.2.eng: There are these seven successes for a lay follower.

an7.31:1.4.eng: They don’t miss out on seeing the mendicants.

an7.31:1.5.eng: They don’t neglect listening to the true teaching.

an7.31:1.6.eng: They train in higher ethical conduct.

an7.31:1.7.eng: They’re very confident about mendicants, whether senior, junior, or middle.

an7.31:1.8.pli: bhikkhūsu theresu ceva navesu ca majjhimesu ca anupārambhacitto dhammaṃ suṇāti na randhagavesī,
an7.31:1.8.eng: They don’t listen to the teaching with a hostile, fault-finding mind.

an7.31:1.9.eng: They don’t seek outside of the Buddhist community for those worthy of religious donations.

an7.31:1.10.eng: And they serve the Buddhist community first.

an7.31:1.11.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, satta upāsakassa sambhavāti.
an7.31:1.11.eng: These are the seven successes for a lay follower.

an7.31:2.1.eng: A lay follower misses out on seeing

an7.31:2.3.eng: and listening to the teachings of the Noble One.

an7.31:2.4.eng: They don’t train in higher ethical conduct,

an7.31:3.3.eng: They want to listen to the true teaching

an7.31:4.1.eng: They seek outside the Buddhist community

an7.31:4.2.eng: for someone else worthy of religious donations,

an7.31:5.1.eng: These seven principles leading to decline

an7.31:5.3.eng: A lay follower who practices these

an7.31:5.4.eng: falls away from the true teaching.

an7.31:6.1.eng: A lay follower doesn’t miss out on seeing

an7.31:6.3.eng: and listening to the teachings of the Noble One.

an7.31:6.4.eng: They train in higher ethical conduct,

an7.31:7.3.eng: They want to listen to the true teaching

an7.31:8.1.eng: They don’t seek outside the Buddhist community

an7.31:8.2.eng: for someone else worthy of religious donations,

an7.31:9.1.eng: These seven principles that prevent decline

an7.31:9.3.eng: A lay follower who practices them

an7.31:9.4.eng: doesn’t fall away from the true teaching.”

an7.32:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.32:1.1.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

an7.32:2.1.eng: “Sir, these seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an7.32:2.3.pli: Satthugāravatā, dhammagāravatā, saṅghagāravatā, sikkhāgāravatā, samādhigāravatā, appamādagāravatā, paṭisanthāragāravatā.
an7.32:2.3.eng: Respect for the Teacher, for the teaching, for the Saṅgha, for the training, for immersion, for diligence, and for hospitality.

an7.32:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhante, satta dhammā bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an7.32:2.4.eng: These seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.”

an7.32:2.7.pli: Atha kho sā devatā “samanuñño me satthā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyi.
an7.32:2.7.eng: Then that deity, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

an7.32:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
an7.32:3.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened, adding:

an7.32:3.2.pli: “imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhikkhave, sā devatā maṃ etadavoca:

an7.32:3.5.pli: Satthugāravatā, dhammagāravatā, saṅghagāravatā, sikkhāgāravatā, samādhigāravatā, appamādagāravatā, paṭisanthāragāravatā—

an7.32:3.6.pli: ime kho, bhante, satta dhammā bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī’ti.

an7.32:3.8.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.

an7.32:4.1.eng: “Respect for the Teacher and the teaching,

an7.32:4.2.eng: and keen respect for the Saṅgha;

an7.32:4.4.eng: and keen respect for the training.

an7.32:5.4.eng: and has drawn near to extinguishment.”

an7.33:1.1.pli: “Imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhikkhave, sā devatā maṃ etadavoca:
an7.33:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, tonight, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side, and said to me:

an7.33:1.2.eng: ‘Sir, these seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an7.33:1.4.pli: Satthugāravatā, dhammagāravatā, saṅghagāravatā, sikkhāgāravatā, samādhigāravatā, hirigāravatā, ottappagāravatā.
an7.33:1.4.eng: Respect for the Teacher, for the teaching, for the Saṅgha, for the training, for immersion, for conscience, and for prudence.

an7.33:1.5.pli: Ime kho, bhante, satta dhammā bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī’ti.
an7.33:1.5.eng: These seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.’

an7.33:1.6.eng: That is what that deity said.

an7.33:1.7.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
an7.33:1.7.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.

an7.33:2.1.eng: One respectful of the Teacher and the teaching,

an7.33:3.3.eng: it is impossible for them to decline;

an7.33:3.4.eng: they have drawn near to extinguishment.”

an7.34:1.1.pli: “Imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ aññatarā devatā …pe… maṃ etadavoca:
an7.34:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, tonight a deity … said to me:

an7.34:1.2.eng: ‘Sir, these seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an7.34:1.4.pli: Satthugāravatā, dhammagāravatā, saṅghagāravatā, sikkhāgāravatā, samādhigāravatā, sovacassatā, kalyāṇamittatā.
an7.34:1.4.eng: Respect for the Teacher, for the teaching, for the Saṅgha, for the training, for immersion; being easy to admonish, and good friendship.

an7.34:1.5.pli: Ime kho, bhante, satta dhammā bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī’ti.
an7.34:1.5.eng: These seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.’

an7.34:1.6.eng: That is what that deity said.

an7.34:1.7.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
an7.34:1.7.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.

an7.34:2.1.eng: Respect for the Teacher and the teaching,

an7.34:2.2.eng: and keen respect for the Saṅgha;

an7.34:2.4.eng: and keen respect for the training.

an7.34:3.1.eng: One with good friends, easy to admonish,

an7.34:3.4.eng: and has drawn near to extinguishment.”

an7.35:1.1.pli: “Imaṃ, bhikkhave, rattiṃ aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā …pe…
an7.35:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, tonight a deity … said to me:

an7.35:1.2.eng: ‘Sir, these seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.

an7.35:1.4.pli: Satthugāravatā, dhammagāravatā, saṅghagāravatā, sikkhāgāravatā, samādhigāravatā, sovacassatā, kalyāṇamittatā.
an7.35:1.4.eng: Respect for the Teacher, for the teaching, for the Saṅgha, for the training, for immersion; being easy to admonish, and good friendship.

an7.35:1.5.pli: Ime kho, bhante, satta dhammā bhikkhuno aparihānāya saṃvattantī’ti.
an7.35:1.5.eng: These seven things don’t lead to the decline of a mendicant trainee.’

an7.35:1.6.eng: That is what that deity said.

an7.35:1.7.pli: Idaṃ vatvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyī”ti.
an7.35:1.7.eng: Then he bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on his right side, before vanishing right there.”

an7.35:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.35:2.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha:

an7.35:2.2.pli: “imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi.
an7.35:2.2.eng: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

an7.35:2.3.pli: Idha, bhante, bhikkhu attanā ca satthugāravo hoti, satthugāravatāya ca vaṇṇavādī.
an7.35:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant personally respects the Teacher and praises such respect.

an7.35:2.4.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū na satthugāravā te ca satthugāravatāya samādapeti.
an7.35:2.4.eng: And they encourage other mendicants who lack such respect to respect the Teacher.

an7.35:2.5.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū satthugāravā tesañca vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.
an7.35:2.5.eng: And they praise other mendicants who respect the Teacher at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an7.35:2.10.eng: They are personally easy to admonish …

an7.35:2.11.eng: They personally have good friends, and praise such friendship.

an7.35:2.12.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū na kalyāṇamittā te ca kalyāṇamittatāya samādapeti.
an7.35:2.12.eng: And they encourage other mendicants who lack good friends to develop good friendship.

an7.35:2.13.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū kalyāṇamittā tesañca vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālenāti.
an7.35:2.13.eng: And they praise other mendicants who have good friends at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an7.35:2.14.pli: Imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
an7.35:2.14.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

an7.35:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, sāriputta, imassa mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
an7.35:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

an7.35:3.3.pli: Idha, sāriputta, bhikkhu attanā ca satthugāravo hoti, satthugāravatāya ca vaṇṇavādī.
an7.35:3.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant personally respects the Teacher …

an7.35:3.4.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū na satthugāravā te ca satthugāravatāya samādapeti.
an7.35:3.4.eng: And they encourage other mendicants who lack such respect to respect the Teacher.

an7.35:3.5.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū satthugāravā tesañca vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālena.
an7.35:3.5.eng: And they praise other mendicants who respect the Teacher at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an7.35:3.10.eng: They are personally easy to admonish …

an7.35:3.11.eng: They personally have good friends, and praise such friendship.

an7.35:3.12.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū na kalyāṇamittā te ca kalyāṇamittatāya samādapeti.
an7.35:3.12.eng: And they encourage other mendicants who lack good friends to develop good friendship.

an7.35:3.13.pli: Ye caññe bhikkhū kalyāṇamittā tesañca vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇati bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ kālenāti.
an7.35:3.13.eng: And they praise other mendicants who have good friends at the right time, truthfully and correctly.

an7.35:3.14.pli: Imassa kho, sāriputta, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti.
an7.35:3.14.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.”

an7.36:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should associate with a friend who has seven factors.

an7.36:1.3.pli: Duddadaṃ dadāti, dukkaraṃ karoti, dukkhamaṃ khamati, guyhamassa āvi karoti, guyhamassa pariguhati, āpadāsu na jahati, khīṇena nātimaññati.
an7.36:1.3.eng: They give what is hard to give. They do what is hard to do. They endure what is hard to endure. They reveal their secrets to you. They keep your secrets. They don’t abandon you in times of trouble. They don’t look down on you in times of loss.

an7.36:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi aṅgehi samannāgato mitto sevitabboti.
an7.36:1.4.eng: You should associate with a friend who has these seven factors.

an7.36:2.1.eng: A friend gives what is hard to give,

an7.36:2.2.eng: and does what’s hard to do.

an7.36:2.3.eng: They put up with your harsh words,

an7.36:2.4.eng: and with things hard to endure.

an7.36:3.2.eng: and keep your secrets for you.

an7.36:3.3.eng: They don’t abandon you in times of trouble,

an7.36:3.4.eng: or look down on you in times of loss.

an7.36:4.2.eng: these things are found is your friend.

an7.36:4.3.eng: If you want to have a friend,

an7.36:4.4.eng: you should keep company with that sort.”

an7.37:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu mitto sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo api panujjamānenapi.
an7.37:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a friend has seven qualities you should associate with, accompany, and attend them, even if they drive you away.

an7.37:1.3.pli: Piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca vattā ca vacanakkhamo ca gambhīrañca kathaṃ kattā hoti, no ca aṭṭhāne niyojeti.
an7.37:1.3.eng: They’re likable, agreeable, respected, and admired. They admonish you and they accept admonishment. They speak on deep matters. And they don’t urge you to do bad things.

an7.37:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu mitto sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo api panujjamānenapīti.
an7.37:1.4.eng: When a friend has these seven qualities you should associate with, accompany, and attend them, even if they drive you away.

an7.37:2.4.eng: and doesn’t urge you to do bad.

an7.37:3.2.eng: these things are found is your friend.

an7.37:3.3.eng: If you want to have a friend,

an7.37:3.5.eng: then even if they chase you away,

an7.37:3.6.eng: you should keep company with that sort.”

an7.38:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nacirasseva catasso paṭisambhidā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya.
an7.38:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities will soon realize the four kinds of textual analysis and live having achieved them with their own insight.

an7.38:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ me cetaso līnattan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
an7.38:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is mental sluggishness’.

an7.38:1.4.pli: ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘ajjhattaṃ me saṅkhittaṃ cittan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
an7.38:1.4.eng: They truly understand internally constricted mind as ‘internally constricted mind’.

an7.38:1.5.pli: bahiddhā vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘bahiddhā me vikkhittaṃ cittan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
an7.38:1.5.eng: They truly understand externally scattered mind as ‘externally scattered mind’.

an7.38:1.6.pli: tassa viditā vedanā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti;
an7.38:1.6.eng: They know feelings as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

an7.38:1.7.pli: viditā saññā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti;
an7.38:1.7.eng: They know perceptions as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

an7.38:1.8.pli: viditā vitakkā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti;
an7.38:1.8.eng: They know thoughts as they arise, as they remain, and as they go away.

an7.38:1.9.pli: sappāyāsappāyesu kho panassa dhammesu hīnappaṇītesu kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgesu nimittaṃ suggahitaṃ hoti sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya.
an7.38:1.9.eng: The patterns of qualities—suitable or unsuitable, inferior or superior, or those on the side of dark or bright—are properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom.

an7.38:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nacirasseva catasso paṭisambhidā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā”ti.
an7.38:1.10.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities will soon realize the four kinds of textual analysis and live having achieved them with their own insight.”

an7.39:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto catasso paṭisambhidā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an7.39:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, having seven qualities, Sāriputta realized the four kinds of textual analysis and lives having achieved them with his own insight.

an7.39:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sāriputto ‘idaṃ me cetaso līnattan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
an7.39:1.3.eng: It’s when Sāriputta truly understood: ‘This is mental sluggishness’.

an7.39:1.4.pli: ajjhattaṃ saṅkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘ajjhattaṃ me saṅkhittaṃ cittan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
an7.39:1.4.eng: He truly understood internally constricted mind as ‘internally constricted mind’.

an7.39:1.5.pli: bahiddhā vikkhittaṃ vā cittaṃ ‘bahiddhā me vikkhittaṃ cittan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti;
an7.39:1.5.eng: He truly understood externally scattered mind as ‘externally scattered mind’.

an7.39:1.6.pli: tassa viditā vedanā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti;
an7.39:1.6.eng: He knew feelings, perceptions, and thoughts as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.

an7.39:1.8.pli: vitakkā uppajjanti, viditā upaṭṭhahanti, viditā abbhatthaṃ gacchanti;

an7.39:1.9.pli: sappāyāsappāyesu kho panassa dhammesu hīnappaṇītesu kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgesu nimittaṃ suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ sūpadhāritaṃ suppaṭividdhaṃ paññāya.
an7.39:1.9.eng: The patterns of qualities—suitable or unsuitable, inferior or superior, or those on the side of dark or bright—were properly grasped, focused on, borne in mind, and penetrated with wisdom.

an7.39:1.10.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto catasso paṭisambhidā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
an7.39:1.10.eng: Having these seven qualities, Sāriputta realized the four kinds of textual analysis and lives having achieved them with his own insight.”

an7.4:1.3.pli: Saddhābalaṃ, vīriyabalaṃ, hirībalaṃ, ottappabalaṃ, satibalaṃ, samādhibalaṃ, paññābalaṃ.
an7.4:1.3.eng: The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

an7.4:2.1.eng: And what is the power of faith?

an7.4:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
an7.4:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:

an7.4:2.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho …pe… satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
an7.4:2.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

an7.4:2.4.eng: This is called the power of faith.

an7.4:3.1.eng: And what is the power of energy?

an7.4:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako āraddhavīriyo viharati akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya, thāmavā daḷhaparakkamo anikkhittadhuro kusalesu dhammesu.
an7.4:3.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple lives with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.

an7.4:3.3.eng: This is called the power of energy.

an7.4:4.1.eng: And what is the power of conscience?

an7.4:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako hirīmā hoti, hirīyati kāyaduccaritena vacīduccaritena manoduccaritena, hirīyati pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā.
an7.4:4.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has a conscience. They’re conscientious about bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and conscientious about acquiring any bad, unskillful qualities.

an7.4:4.3.eng: This is called the power of conscience.

an7.4:5.1.eng: And what is the power of prudence?

an7.4:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ottappī hoti, ottappati kāyaduccaritena vacīduccaritena manoduccaritena, ottappati pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā.
an7.4:5.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is prudent. They’re prudent when it comes to bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and prudent when it comes to the acquiring of any bad, unskillful qualities.

an7.4:5.3.eng: This is called the power of prudence.

an7.4:6.1.eng: And what is the power of mindfulness?

an7.4:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako satimā hoti paramena satinepakkena samannāgato cirakatampi cirabhāsitampi saritā anussaritā.
an7.4:6.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.

an7.4:6.3.eng: This is called the power of mindfulness.

an7.4:7.1.eng: And what is the power of immersion?

an7.4:7.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected. …

an7.4:7.4.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

an7.4:7.5.eng: This is called the power of immersion.

an7.4:8.1.eng: And what is the power of wisdom?

an7.4:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti udayatthagāminiyā paññāya samannāgato ariyāya nibbedhikāya sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an7.4:8.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an7.4:8.3.eng: This is called the power of wisdom.

an7.4:10.1.eng: The powers are faith and energy,

an7.4:10.4.eng: and wisdom as the seventh power.

an7.4:11.1.eng: They should examine the teaching rationally,

an7.4:11.4.eng: is like a lamp going out.”

an7.40:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu cittaṃ vase vatteti, no ca bhikkhu cittassa vasena vattati.
an7.40:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities masters their mind and is not mastered by it.

an7.40:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu samādhikusalo hoti, samādhissa samāpattikusalo hoti, samādhissa ṭhitikusalo hoti, samādhissa vuṭṭhānakusalo hoti, samādhissa kalyāṇakusalo hoti, samādhissa gocarakusalo hoti, samādhissa abhinīhārakusalo hoti.
an7.40:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is skilled at immersion, skilled in entering immersion, skilled in remaining in immersion, skilled in emerging from immersion, skilled in positivity for immersion, skilled in the territory of immersion, and skilled in projecting the mind purified by immersion.

an7.40:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu cittaṃ vase vatteti, no ca bhikkhu cittassa vasena vattatī”ti.
an7.40:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities masters their mind and is not mastered by it.”

an7.41:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto cittaṃ vase vatteti, no ca sāriputto cittassa vasena vattati.
an7.41:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, having seven qualities Sāriputta has mastered his mind and is not mastered by it.

an7.41:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sāriputto samādhikusalo hoti, samādhissa samāpattikusalo, samādhissa ṭhitikusalo, samādhissa vuṭṭhānakusalo, samādhissa kalyāṇakusalo, samādhissa gocarakusalo, samādhissa abhinīhārakusalo hoti.
an7.41:1.3.eng: Sāriputta is skilled at immersion, skilled in entering immersion, skilled in remaining in immersion, skilled in emerging from immersion, skilled in positivity for immersion, skilled in the territory of immersion, and skilled in projecting the mind purified by immersion.

an7.41:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto cittaṃ vase vatteti, no ca sāriputto cittassa vasena vattatī”ti.
an7.41:1.4.eng: Having these seven qualities Sāriputta has mastered his mind and is not mastered by it.”
